cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
who developed the central processing unit (cpu)
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
1. The central processing unit (CPU) is a critical component of computers, responsible for executing instructions and processing data.
2. The development of the CPU was not the work of a single individual but rather a series of advancements made by various engineers and companies over time.
3. The first commercially available CPU is often credited to Intel, specifically the Intel 4004, which was released in 1971. This was developed by a team led by Marcian Hoff, along with Federico Faggin and Ted Hoff.
4. Prior to the Intel 4004, there were other forms of processors and computing devices, but they were not integrated circuits in the way we think of CPUs today.
5. Therefore, while many individuals contributed to the evolution of the CPU, the Intel 4004 is a significant milestone in its development.

Answer:
The central processing unit (CPU) was developed by a team at Intel, notably Marcian Hoff, Federico Faggin, and Ted Hoff, with the release of the Intel 4004 in 1971.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who developed the central processing unit (cpu)
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
["The concept of a single-chip microprocessor CPU (central processing unit) was conceived in a 1968 meeting in Japan between Sharp engineer Tadashi Sasaki and an unnamed female software engineering researcher from Nara Women's College. He discussed the concept at a brainstorming meeting that was held in Japan. Sasaki attributes the basic invention to break the chipset of a calculator into four parts with ROM (4001), RAM (4002), shift registers (4003) and CPU (4004) to an unnamed woman, a software engineering researcher from Nara Women's College, who was present at the meeting. Sasaki then had his first meeting with Noyce in 1968. Sasaki discussed the microprocessor concept with Busicom and Intel in 1968, and presented the woman's four-division chipset concept to Intel and Busicom. This provided the basis for the single-chip microprocessor design of the Intel 4004. He was also involved in the development of the Busicom 141-PF desktop calculator which led to the 4004's creation. Sasaki thus played a key role in the creation of the first microprocessor.\n", 'Curry and Hauser had become increasingly interested in the idea of selling their own computers and so, on 5 December 1978, they set up Cambridge Processor Unit Ltd (CPU). Their first customer was Ace Coin Equipment Ltd, who needed controllers for their fruit machines.\n', 'Curry and Hauser decided to pursue their joint interest in microcomputers and, on 5 December 1978, they set up Cambridge Processor Unit Ltd. (CPU) as the vehicle with which to do this. CPU soon obtained a consultancy contract to develop a microprocessor-based controller for a fruit machine for Ace Coin Equipment (ACE) of Wales. The ACE project was started at office space obtained at 4a Market Hill in Cambridge. Initially, the ACE controller was based on a National Semiconductor SC/MP microprocessor, but soon the switch to a MOS Technology 6502 was made.\n', 'Soon designs integrated the control unit and ALU into what became known as the central processing unit (CPU).\n', 'A central processing unit (CPU), also called a central processor or main processor, is the electronic circuitry within a computer that carries out the instructions of a computer program by performing the basic arithmetic, logic, controlling, and input/output (I/O) operations specified by the instructions. The computer industry has used the term "central processing unit" at least since the early 1960s. Traditionally, the term "CPU" refers to a processor, more specifically to its processing unit and control unit (CU), distinguishing these core elements of a computer from external components such as main memory and I/O circuitry.\n', 'BULLET::::- Central processing unit – (CPU) is the electronic circuitry within a computer that carries out the instructions of a computer program by performing the basic arithmetic, logic, controlling and input/output (I/O) operations specified by the instructions. The computer industry has used the term "central processing unit" at least since the early 1960s. Traditionally, the term "CPU" refers to a processor, more specifically to its processing unit and control unit (CU), distinguishing these core elements of a computer from external components such as main memory and I/O circuitry.\n', 'By the late 1960s, designers were striving to integrate the central processing unit (CPU) functions of a computer onto a handful of very-large-scale integration metal-oxide semiconductor chips, called microprocessor unit (MPU) chipsets. Building on an earlier Busicom design from 1969, Intel introduced the first commercial microprocessor, the 4-bit Intel 4004, in 1971, followed by its 8-bit microprocessor 8008 in 1972. In 1969, Lee Boysel, based on the 8-bit arithmetic logic units (3800/3804) he designed earlier at Fairchild, created the Four-Phase Systems Inc. AL-1, an 8-bit CPU slice that was expandable to 32-bits. In 1970, Steve Geller and Ray Holt of Garrett AiResearch designed the MP944 chipset to implement the F-14A Central Air Data Computer on six metal-gate chips fabricated by AMI.\n', 'The Intel 4004 is a 4-bit central processing unit (CPU) released by Intel Corporation in 1971. It was the first commercially available microprocessor, and the first in a long line of Intel CPUs. The silicon design only started in April 1970, when Federico Faggin joined Intel. Until then, the architectural proposal by Marcian Hoff had been idling without further development. Faggin took over the project and led it to its successful completion in January 1971. Masatoshi Shima participated in the architectural phase with Hoff and, later, in the logic design, helping Faggin to speed up the development.\n', "In the 1980s, Moore turned his attention and Forth development techniques to CPU design, developing several stack machine microprocessors and gaining several microprocessor-related patents along the way. His designs have all emphasized high performance at low power usage. He also explored alternate Forth architectures such as cmForth and machine Forth, which more closely matched his chips' machine languages.\n", 'In his early career days, he worked at Pye, Royal Radar Establishment and W.R Grace Laboratories. Then, in April 1966 he joined Sinclair Radionics where he worked for 13 years. He was involved with their hifi products and their electric vehicle. In 1972, he helped Sinclair Radionics to launch its first electronic calculator, the Executive. He set up Cambridge Processor Unit Ltd. (CPU) in December 1978. Their first product was the Acorn Microcomputer (later called the System 1).\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To address the question of who developed the central processing unit (CPU), we can extract and analyze relevant content from the provided passages. Here are the key points and their roles in understanding the development of the CPU:

1. **Tadashi Sasaki and the Concept of the Microprocessor**:
   - The first passage discusses a 1968 meeting in Japan where Sharp engineer Tadashi Sasaki conceived the idea of a single-chip microprocessor CPU. He attributes the basic invention to an unnamed female software engineering researcher from Nara Women's College, who proposed breaking the chipset of a calculator into four parts, including the CPU.
   - **Role**: This passage highlights the collaborative nature of innovation in technology and introduces the idea that the CPU's development was influenced by contributions from multiple individuals, including women, who have historically been underrepresented in technology narratives.

2. **Intel 4004**:
   - The passage mentions that Intel introduced the first commercial microprocessor, the 4-bit Intel 4004, in 1971, which was based on earlier designs from Busicom. It also notes that Federico Faggin played a crucial role in the development of the 4004 after joining Intel.
   - **Role**: This information is critical as it identifies Intel and specific individuals (Faggin, Hoff, and Shima) as key players in the actual development and commercialization of the CPU, marking a significant milestone in computing history.

3. **Historical Context of CPU Development**:
   - Several passages discuss the evolution of the CPU and its functions, including the integration of the control unit and arithmetic logic unit (ALU) into what became known as the CPU. The term "central processing unit" has been used since the early 1960s.
   - **Role**: This context is important for understanding how the CPU evolved from separate components into a unified system, which is foundational to modern computing.

4. **Cambridge Processor Unit Ltd.**:
   - The passages mention Curry and Hauser setting up Cambridge Processor Unit Ltd. in 1978, which indicates the emergence of new companies focused on CPU development during the microcomputer revolution.
   - **Role**: This highlights the diversification of CPU development beyond established companies like Intel, showcasing the growing interest in microcomputers and the entrepreneurial spirit of the time.

5. **Technological Innovations and Contributions**:
   - The mention of various individuals and their contributions to CPU design, such as Lee Boysel and Steve Geller, illustrates the collaborative and competitive nature of the tech industry during the 1960s and 1970s.
   - **Role**: This underscores the importance of innovation and the contributions of various engineers and designers in shaping the CPU landscape, which is essential for understanding the broader context of CPU development.

In summary, the extracted content provides a rich background on the development of the CPU, emphasizing the collaborative nature of technological innovation, the key players involved, and the historical context that led to the creation of the first microprocessors. This understanding is crucial for answering the question about who developed the CPU, as it reveals the multifaceted contributions that led to its inception.

knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

1. The central processing unit (CPU) is a fundamental component of computers, responsible for executing instructions and processing data. It is often referred to as the brain of the computer.

2. The development of the CPU was not the work of a single individual but rather a series of advancements made by various engineers and companies over time. The concept of integrating multiple functions into a single chip was a significant innovation that paved the way for modern CPUs.

3. The first commercially available CPU is often credited to Intel, specifically the Intel 4004, which was released in 1971. This microprocessor was developed by a team led by Marcian Hoff, along with Federico Faggin and Ted Hoff. Faggin played a crucial role in the design and implementation of the 4004 after joining Intel.

4. Prior to the Intel 4004, there were other forms of processors and computing devices, but they were not integrated circuits in the way we think of CPUs today. The passage about Tadashi Sasaki highlights that the idea of a single-chip microprocessor was conceived in 1968, indicating that foundational concepts were being developed before Intel's commercial success.

8. The contributions of women in technology, as noted in the passage about Tadashi Sasaki's meeting, emphasize the collaborative nature of innovation and the often-overlooked roles that diverse individuals have played in technological advancements.

**Answer:**
The central processing unit (CPU) was developed through the collaborative efforts of various engineers and companies over time. The first commercially available CPU is credited to Intel, specifically the Intel 4004, which was released in 1971. This microprocessor was developed by a team led by Marcian Hoff, along with Federico Faggin and Ted Hoff. Additionally, the concept of a single-chip microprocessor was influenced by earlier ideas, including contributions from Tadashi Sasaki and an unnamed female researcher in 1968. The evolution of the CPU involved many innovations and contributions from a diverse group of individuals, marking a significant milestone in the history of computing.

Task Description:
Please extract foundational knowledge that may be familiar to the model or advanced information beyond the model's already familiar foundational knowledge from these passages, and analyze the role of these contents.
Summarize and consolidate these contents, which should deepen the model's understanding of the question through familiarity with these basic and advanced pieces of information. 
This process aims to encourage the model to comprehend the question more thoroughly and expand its knowledge boundaries.

The passages provided contain a mix of foundational and advanced information regarding the development of the central processing unit (CPU). Here’s a summary and analysis of the key points:

### Foundational Knowledge

1. **Definition and Function of CPU**:
   - The CPU is defined as the electronic circuitry within a computer that executes instructions from a computer program, performing basic arithmetic, logic, controlling, and input/output operations. This definition has been in use since at least the early 1960s.

2. **Historical Context**:
   - The term "central processing unit" has been used in the computer industry since the early 1960s, indicating the long-standing recognition of this component's importance in computing.

3. **Integration of Components**:
   - By the late 1960s, there was a significant push to integrate CPU functions onto fewer chips, leading to the development of microprocessors.

### Advanced Information

1. **Development of the First Microprocessor**:
   - The Intel 4004, released in 1971, is noted as the first commercially available microprocessor. Its development involved key figures such as Federico Faggin, who led the project after Marcian Hoff's architectural proposal. Masatoshi Shima also contributed to the design.

2. **Contributions of Individuals**:
   - The passages highlight the contributions of various engineers and researchers, such as Tadashi Sasaki, who played a crucial role in the conceptualization of the microprocessor during a meeting in Japan in 1968. An unnamed female researcher also contributed significantly to the chipset design.

3. **Evolution of CPU Design**:
   - The transition from discrete components to integrated circuits and the eventual creation of microprocessors marked a significant evolution in CPU design. This evolution is exemplified by the Intel 4004 and its successors.

4. **Commercialization and Impact**:
   - The establishment of companies like Cambridge Processor Unit Ltd. in 1978 indicates the growing commercial interest in CPU technology and microcomputers, which would shape the future of computing.

### Analysis of Role

The foundational knowledge establishes a clear understanding of what a CPU is and its essential functions within a computer system. This is crucial for anyone studying computer science or engineering, as it forms the basis for more complex concepts related to computer architecture and design.

The advanced information provides context about the historical development of the CPU, highlighting key figures and milestones that contributed to its evolution. This knowledge not only enriches the understanding of the CPU's technical aspects but also illustrates the collaborative nature of technological advancement, where multiple individuals and companies contribute to a single innovation.

### Conclusion

By consolidating both foundational and advanced knowledge, one gains a comprehensive view of the CPU's development. Understanding the historical context, key contributors, and the evolution of technology enhances the comprehension of how CPUs have shaped modern computing. This deeper understanding can inform future studies in computer architecture, design, and the ongoing advancements in microprocessor technology.

Generation Format:
knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

1. **Definition and Role of the CPU**:
   - The central processing unit (CPU) is the primary component of a computer that performs calculations and executes instructions from programs. It is often referred to as the "brain" of the computer, handling arithmetic, logic, control, and input/output operations.

2. **Historical Context of CPU Development**:
   - The term "central processing unit" has been in use since the early 1960s, reflecting the importance of this component in computing. The evolution of the CPU has been marked by significant technological advancements, particularly the shift from discrete components to integrated circuits.

3. **Key Milestones in CPU Development**:
   - The Intel 4004, released in 1971, is recognized as the first commercially available microprocessor. This development was a collaborative effort involving key figures such as Marcian Hoff, who proposed the architecture, and Federico Faggin, who led the design and implementation. Masatoshi Shima also played a role in the project.

4. **Contributions from Various Engineers**:
   - The development of the CPU was not solely the work of Intel. Engineers like Tadashi Sasaki contributed to the conceptualization of microprocessors, indicating that the evolution of CPU technology involved multiple contributors and ideas over time.

5. **Impact of Microprocessor Technology**:
   - The introduction of microprocessors like the Intel 4004 marked a significant turning point in computing, leading to the development of personal computers and the proliferation of computing technology in everyday life. The establishment of companies focused on microprocessor technology, such as Cambridge Processor Unit Ltd. in 1978, further illustrates the growing commercial interest and innovation in this field.

6. **Collaborative Nature of Technological Advancement**:
   - The history of the CPU highlights the collaborative nature of technological progress, where innovations build upon previous ideas and contributions from various individuals and organizations.

### Answer:
The central processing unit (CPU) was developed through a collaborative effort involving multiple engineers and companies, with the Intel 4004, released in 1971, being the first commercially available microprocessor. Key figures in its development included Marcian Hoff, who proposed the architecture, and Federico Faggin, who led the design and implementation. Additionally, contributions from engineers like Tadashi Sasaki and others played a significant role in the evolution of CPU technology, marking a pivotal moment in the history of computing.

', 'Soon designs integrated the control unit and ALU into what became known as the central processing unit (CPU).
', 'A central processing unit (CPU), also called a central processor or main processor, is the electronic circuitry within a computer that carries out the instructions of a computer program by performing the basic arithmetic, logic, controlling, and input/output (I/O) operations specified by the instructions. The computer industry has used the term "central processing unit" at least since the early 1960s. Traditionally, the term "CPU" refers to a processor, more specifically to its processing unit and control unit (CU), distinguishing these core elements of a computer from external components such as main memory and I/O circuitry.
', 'BULLET::::- Central processing unit – (CPU) is the electronic circuitry within a computer that carries out the instructions of a computer program by performing the basic arithmetic, logic, controlling and input/output (I/O) operations specified by the instructions. The computer industry has used the term "central processing unit" at least since the early 1960s. Traditionally, the term "CPU" refers to a processor, more specifically to its processing unit and control unit (CU), distinguishing these core elements of a computer from external components such as main memory and I/O circuitry.
', 'By the late 1960s, designers were striving to integrate the central processing unit (CPU) functions of a computer onto a handful of very-large-scale integration metal-oxide semiconductor chips, called microprocessor unit (MPU) chipsets. Building on an earlier Busicom design from 1969, Intel introduced the first commercial microprocessor, the 4-bit Intel 4004, in 1971, followed by its 8-bit microprocessor 8008 in 1972. In 1969, Lee Boysel, based on the 8-bit arithmetic logic units (3800/3804) he designed earlier at Fairchild, created the Four-Phase Systems Inc. AL-1, an 8-bit CPU slice that was expandable to 32-bits. In 1970, Steve Geller and Ray Holt of Garrett AiResearch designed the MP944 chipset to implement the F-14A Central Air Data Computer on six metal-gate chips fabricated by AMI.
', 'The Intel 4004 is a 4-bit central processing unit (CPU) released by Intel Corporation in 1971. It was the first commercially available microprocessor, and the first in a long line of Intel CPUs. The silicon design only started in April 1970, when Federico Faggin joined Intel. Until then, the architectural proposal by Marcian Hoff had been idling without further development. Faggin took over the project and led it to its successful completion in January 1971. Masatoshi Shima participated in the architectural phase with Hoff and, later, in the logic design, helping Faggin to speed up the development.
', "In the 1980s, Moore turned his attention and Forth development techniques to CPU design, developing several stack machine microprocessors and gaining several microprocessor-related patents along the way. His designs have all emphasized high performance at low power usage. He also explored alternate Forth architectures such as cmForth and machine Forth, which more closely matched his chips' machine languages.
", 'In his early career days, he worked at Pye, Royal Radar Establishment and W.R Grace Laboratories. Then, in April 1966 he joined Sinclair Radionics where he worked for 13 years. He was involved with their hifi products and their electric vehicle. In 1972, he helped Sinclair Radionics to launch its first electronic calculator, the Executive. He set up Cambridge Processor Unit Ltd. (CPU) in December 1978. Their first product was the Acorn Microcomputer (later called the System 1).
']

Task Description:
Please extract content from these passages that can help enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities.
consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate key information from the provided passages regarding the development of the central processing unit (CPU). Here’s a summary of the relevant content:

1. **Historical Context and Key Figures**:
   - The concept of a single-chip microprocessor CPU was conceived in a 1968 meeting in Japan involving Sharp engineer Tadashi Sasaki and an unnamed female software engineering researcher. This meeting led to the idea of breaking down the chipset of a calculator into four parts, which included the CPU.
   - The Intel 4004, released in 1971, was the first commercially available microprocessor. The project was led by Federico Faggin, who joined Intel in 1970 and took over the architectural proposal initially made by Marcian Hoff. Masatoshi Shima also contributed to the architectural and logic design.

2. **Development Process**:
   - The development of the Intel 4004 was a collaborative effort that involved brainstorming and discussions among engineers, highlighting the importance of teamwork and the sharing of ideas in technological advancements.
   - The transition from conceptualization to actual product (the Intel 4004) involved overcoming challenges in design and integration, showcasing the iterative nature of technological development.

3. **Technological Evolution**:
   - By the late 1960s, there was a push to integrate CPU functions onto fewer chips, leading to the development of microprocessor unit (MPU) chipsets. This reflects a trend in the industry towards miniaturization and efficiency.
   - The passage mentions other early CPU designs, such as the Four-Phase Systems Inc. AL-1 and the MP944 chipset, indicating a broader context of innovation in CPU design during that era.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:

1. **Understanding Causality**:
   - The information illustrates how specific meetings and discussions (causal events) led to significant technological advancements (effects), such as the development of the Intel 4004. This helps the model understand the cause-and-effect relationships in technological innovation.

2. **Collaborative Dynamics**:
   - The emphasis on teamwork and collaboration among engineers highlights how multiple inputs and perspectives can lead to successful outcomes. This understanding can improve the model's ability to infer the importance of collaboration in achieving complex tasks.

3. **Iterative Development**:
   - The iterative nature of the design process, where initial ideas evolve through discussion and experimentation, can inform the model about the non-linear paths of innovation. This can enhance its reasoning about how solutions are often reached through trial and error rather than a straightforward process.

4. **Contextual Awareness**:
   - By recognizing the historical context and contributions of various individuals, the model can better infer the significance of different factors in technological advancements. This contextual awareness can lead to more nuanced reasoning about the development of technologies.

5. **Trends in Technology**:
   - Understanding the trends towards integration and miniaturization in CPU design can help the model make logical inferences about future technological developments and their implications.

In summary, the extracted content provides a rich basis for enhancing the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities by illustrating the interconnectedness of ideas, the importance of collaboration, and the iterative nature of technological development. This understanding can lead to more sophisticated reasoning about historical and future technological advancements.

question:
who developed the central processing unit (cpu)
answer:
Reasoning process:
1. The central processing unit (CPU) is a critical component of computers, responsible for executing instructions and processing data.
2. The development of the CPU was not the work of a single individual but rather a series of advancements made by various engineers and companies over time.
3. The first commercially available CPU is often credited to Intel, specifically the Intel 4004, which was released in 1971. This was developed by a team led by Marcian Hoff, along with Federico Faggin and Ted Hoff.
4. Prior to the Intel 4004, there were other forms of processors and computing devices, but they were not integrated circuits in the way we think of CPUs today.
5. Therefore, while many individuals contributed to the evolution of the CPU, the Intel 4004 is a significant milestone in its development.

Answer:
The central processing unit (CPU) was developed by a team at Intel, notably Marcian Hoff, Federico Faggin, and Ted Hoff, with the release of the Intel 4004 in 1971.

knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

1. **Definition and Importance of CPU**:
   - The central processing unit (CPU) is a fundamental component of computers, responsible for executing instructions and processing data. It serves as the brain of the computer, performing essential functions that enable software to run.

2. **Historical Development**:
   - The development of the CPU was not the result of a single individual's efforts but rather a culmination of contributions from various engineers and companies over time. The concept of a single-chip microprocessor was first conceived in a 1968 meeting in Japan involving Sharp engineer Tadashi Sasaki and an unnamed female software engineering researcher, which led to the idea of breaking down the chipset of a calculator into four parts, including the CPU.

3. **Significant Milestone - Intel 4004**:
   - The first commercially available CPU is often credited to Intel, specifically the Intel 4004, released in 1971. This project was led by a team that included Marcian Hoff, Federico Faggin, and Masatoshi Shima. Faggin took over the architectural proposal initially made by Hoff and was instrumental in bringing the project to completion.

4. **Collaborative Efforts**:
   - The development of the Intel 4004 exemplified collaborative efforts among engineers, highlighting the importance of teamwork and the sharing of ideas in technological advancements. This collaborative dynamic is crucial in understanding how complex technologies evolve.

5. **Technological Evolution and Trends**:
   - By the late 1960s, there was a significant push towards integrating CPU functions onto fewer chips, reflecting a trend in the industry towards miniaturization and efficiency. This evolution is evident in the transition from earlier computing devices to the more sophisticated microprocessors we recognize today.

6. **Iterative Development Process**:
   - The transition from conceptualization to actual product involved overcoming various design and integration challenges, showcasing the iterative nature of technological development. This iterative process often involves trial and error, where initial ideas are refined through discussion and experimentation.

7. **Contextual Awareness**:
   - Recognizing the historical context and contributions of various individuals allows for a better understanding of the significance of different factors in technological advancements. This contextual awareness enhances the model's ability to reason about the development of technologies.

8. **Future Implications**:
   - Understanding the trends towards integration and miniaturization in CPU design can help infer future technological developments and their implications, allowing for more sophisticated reasoning about the trajectory of technology.

### Answer:
The central processing unit (CPU) was developed through a collaborative effort by engineers at Intel, notably Marcian Hoff, Federico Faggin, and Masatoshi Shima, culminating in the release of the Intel 4004 in 1971. This CPU is recognized as the first commercially available microprocessor, marking a significant milestone in the evolution of computing technology. The concept of a single-chip microprocessor was initially conceived in a 1968 meeting involving Tadashi Sasaki and an unnamed female researcher, highlighting the importance of collaboration and iterative development in technological advancements.

question_info.question: who developed the central processing unit (cpu)
passages:
The concept of a single-chip microprocessor CPU (central processing unit) was conceived in a 1968 meeting in Japan between Sharp engineer Tadashi Sasaki and an unnamed female software engineering researcher from Nara Women's College. He discussed the concept at a brainstorming meeting that was held in Japan. Sasaki attributes the basic invention to break the chipset of a calculator into four parts with ROM (4001), RAM (4002), shift registers (4003) and CPU (4004) to an unnamed woman, a software engineering researcher from Nara Women's College, who was present at the meeting. Sasaki then had his first meeting with Noyce in 1968. Sasaki discussed the microprocessor concept with Busicom and Intel in 1968, and presented the woman's four-division chipset concept to Intel and Busicom. This provided the basis for the single-chip microprocessor design of the Intel 4004. He was also involved in the development of the Busicom 141-PF desktop calculator which led to the 4004's creation. Sasaki thus played a key role in the creation of the first microprocessor.
Curry and Hauser had become increasingly interested in the idea of selling their own computers and so, on 5 December 1978, they set up Cambridge Processor Unit Ltd (CPU). Their first customer was Ace Coin Equipment Ltd, who needed controllers for their fruit machines.
Curry and Hauser decided to pursue their joint interest in microcomputers and, on 5 December 1978, they set up Cambridge Processor Unit Ltd. (CPU) as the vehicle with which to do this. CPU soon obtained a consultancy contract to develop a microprocessor-based controller for a fruit machine for Ace Coin Equipment (ACE) of Wales. The ACE project was started at office space obtained at 4a Market Hill in Cambridge. Initially, the ACE controller was based on a National Semiconductor SC/MP microprocessor, but soon the switch to a MOS Technology 6502 was made.
Soon designs integrated the control unit and ALU into what became known as the central processing unit (CPU).
A central processing unit (CPU), also called a central processor or main processor, is the electronic circuitry within a computer that carries out the instructions of a computer program by performing the basic arithmetic, logic, controlling, and input/output (I/O) operations specified by the instructions. The computer industry has used the term "central processing unit" at least since the early 1960s. Traditionally, the term "CPU" refers to a processor, more specifically to its processing unit and control unit (CU), distinguishing these core elements of a computer from external components such as main memory and I/O circuitry.
BULLET::::- Central processing unit – (CPU) is the electronic circuitry within a computer that carries out the instructions of a computer program by performing the basic arithmetic, logic, controlling and input/output (I/O) operations specified by the instructions. The computer industry has used the term "central processing unit" at least since the early 1960s. Traditionally, the term "CPU" refers to a processor, more specifically to its processing unit and control unit (CU), distinguishing these core elements of a computer from external components such as main memory and I/O circuitry.
By the late 1960s, designers were striving to integrate the central processing unit (CPU) functions of a computer onto a handful of very-large-scale integration metal-oxide semiconductor chips, called microprocessor unit (MPU) chipsets. Building on an earlier Busicom design from 1969, Intel introduced the first commercial microprocessor, the 4-bit Intel 4004, in 1971, followed by its 8-bit microprocessor 8008 in 1972. In 1969, Lee Boysel, based on the 8-bit arithmetic logic units (3800/3804) he designed earlier at Fairchild, created the Four-Phase Systems Inc. AL-1, an 8-bit CPU slice that was expandable to 32-bits. In 1970, Steve Geller and Ray Holt of Garrett AiResearch designed the MP944 chipset to implement the F-14A Central Air Data Computer on six metal-gate chips fabricated by AMI.
The Intel 4004 is a 4-bit central processing unit (CPU) released by Intel Corporation in 1971. It was the first commercially available microprocessor, and the first in a long line of Intel CPUs. The silicon design only started in April 1970, when Federico Faggin joined Intel. Until then, the architectural proposal by Marcian Hoff had been idling without further development. Faggin took over the project and led it to its successful completion in January 1971. Masatoshi Shima participated in the architectural phase with Hoff and, later, in the logic design, helping Faggin to speed up the development.
In the 1980s, Moore turned his attention and Forth development techniques to CPU design, developing several stack machine microprocessors and gaining several microprocessor-related patents along the way. His designs have all emphasized high performance at low power usage. He also explored alternate Forth architectures such as cmForth and machine Forth, which more closely matched his chips' machine languages.
In his early career days, he worked at Pye, Royal Radar Establishment and W.R Grace Laboratories. Then, in April 1966 he joined Sinclair Radionics where he worked for 13 years. He was involved with their hifi products and their electric vehicle. In 1972, he helped Sinclair Radionics to launch its first electronic calculator, the Executive. He set up Cambridge Processor Unit Ltd. (CPU) in December 1978. Their first product was the Acorn Microcomputer (later called the System 1).
